messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:53): could someone explain to me why the minutes aren't an acceptable transcript of the meetings anymore?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:53): i'm somewhat shocked to discover that the information i've been relying on for the past god knows how many years has suddenly stopped being adequate
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:54): Because it's generally impossible to work out what was said during the meeting based on the minutes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:54): but this only becomes a problem if we also provide an audio transcript?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:55): See mark's talk from earlier
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:55): http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090814#l-510

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, it's because providing the audio for those who can hear it is perceived as providing more information to such people, than is available to the deaf. Whereas with the minutes only, everyone is at an equal disadvantage
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:56): why is it acceptable that people can actually call in then?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:56): surely currently people who can't call in are at a disadvantage too
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:56): But calls aren't on the web, so it's okay
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:57): yes, they are, but accessibility guidelines aren't so extreme as to restrict the use of technology that is inherently inaccessible.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:57): Also: http://twitter.com/diveintomark/status/3310162153
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:57): this is some sort of special mode of thinking that i can't wrap my head around
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (13:58): although, there are relay services that deaf people can use to make phone calls, and could in theory use that for the telcon
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): there are other reasons to not be able to attend the calls
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): like not having a phone, or being asleep
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (13:58): (both of which affect me)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:00): yeah, that's why we still do the important stuff asynchronously

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:01): I personally find the telcons to be of questionable value, and usually choose not to attend. But there are some people who do find them valuable for whatever reason, and there's no reason to restrict them from doing that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): sure, just like there's no reason to restrict publication of audio recordings without transcripts
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:02): but apparently that's not allowed these days
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:03): someone should go tell the podcast industry, btw, that they're all displaying quite unacceptable behaviour
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:04): calls "not it"
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:05): some podcasters do publish transcripts
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:06): i wonder if radio suddenly becomes unacceptable if they start broadcasting on the web, too

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:07): Maybe it's like "You're not having any dessert until you've eaten your greens" where some authority is enforcing rules so that your incentives are aligned with wider benefits than the benefits you care about yourself
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:07): wcag has guidelines about live broadcasts over the internet
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:07): (where dessert is audio recordings, greens is transcripts, and your mother is the W3C)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:08): (I presume this is related to what Wikipedia says is the principal-agent problem)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:10): i don't think anyone in their sane mind would consider comparing listening to audio recordings of htmlwg telecons to my mother's deserts.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:10): but maybe my mother's deserts are just unusally good.

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:13): the problem I see with the arugments about it on public-html is that the accessibility advocates are simply taking the moral high ground, rather than explaning what the actual value of a full text transcript will be in this case and evaluating the cost/benefit ratio
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:15): and they're ignoring the issue that arguments from morality don't carry that much weight with pragmatists
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:15): i am shocked that they would proffer such unnuanced arguments.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:16): I thought the point of accessibility was that it fails when you evaluate the cost/benefit ratio - if it didn't, everyone would make things accessible because it's good business sense, but they don't, and legislation is often needed to skew the ratio
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:17): (Cost/benefit ratios aren't sufficient because they ignore unmeasurable benefits like respecting human rights)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:17): often, the problem is just that people fail to perceive the benefits of making things more accessible
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:18): s/sufficient/a sufficient measure/

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:19): the problem i have with the arguments is that we already have transcripts, and if the transcripts aren't good enough, then that should have been a problem already, and doesn't suddenly become a problem when someone volunteers to provide an additional format.

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:20): that and the fact that it's one hell of a horrible way to run a community if you tell someone who volunteers to do something "sorry but that's not good enough"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:20): when someone volunteers to do something, the right response is "thank you" and "how can i help you"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:23): volunteers to rob a bank
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:23): waits for someone to ask how they can help
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:24): well i was assuming i was talking about people volunteering to do things that actually benefit, or at least affect, the community :-P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (14:25): I'll donate half the money to the members of the WHATWG and HTML WG

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, leaving pubdate in is silly because it's a bad solution to the problem, regardless of whether or not there's another existing way to solve the problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:40): it's not _that_ bad a solution
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:40): we shoud remove pubdate and then focus on finding a better solution, rather than doing it the other way
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:41): it has all the problems of duplicated, hidden metadata
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (14:41): how is that good in any way?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): the perfect is the enemy of the merely good enough. Or in this case, the good is the enemy of the barely ok, but still.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): duplicated hidden metadata is to be discouraged where possible, but dates in general are always hidden data
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): even <time> hides the time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:41): it's not a black-and-white world
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (14:42): and other assorted aphorisms
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (14:42): sees grey, too

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:11): I'm surprised Sam says this working group [htmlwg] has a lot of communication problems, considering other WGs like PF are unable to communicate at all outside telcons
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:11): How far does the scale go?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:11): Maybe you are mistaking quantity of communication for quality
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:13): Communication that doesn't happen is the worst quality of all
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (15:15): Worse than e.g. offensive communication that causes people to stay away and avoid communicating again in the future?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:17): Yes, better to try and fail than never to try at all.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (15:18): Besides, we know from experience that these people tell other people about staying away, so we'll find out about it.
